pyexplainer.pyexplainer_pyexplainer module¶

class pyexplainer.pyexplainer_pyexplainer.PyExplainer(X_train, y_train, indep, dep, class_label=['Clean', 'Defect'], blackbox_model='')[source]¶

Bases: object

A PyExplainer object is able to load training data and ML models to generate human-centric explanation and visualisation

Parameters

  • param1 (pandas.core.frame.DataFrame) – Training data X

  • param2 (pandas.core.series.Series) – Training data y

  • param3 (pandas.core.indexes.base.Index) – to be done…

  • param4 (str) – to be done…

  • param5 (list) – Classification labels, default = [‘Clean’, ‘Defect’]

  • param6 (black box model trained using sklearn) – A black box ML model used to generate the prediction and explanation

Examples

>>> from pyexplainer_pyexplainer import PyExplainer
>>> ...
>>> ...
>>> ...

pyexplainer.pyexplainer_pyexplainer.data_validation(data)[source]¶

Validate the if the given data format is a list of dictionary.

Parameters

param1 (Any) – Data to be validated.

Returns

True: The data is a list of dictionary.

False: The data is not a list of dictionary.

Return type

bool

Examples

>>> from pypkgs import pypkgs
>>> a = pd.Categorical(["character", "hits", "your", "eyeballs"])
>>> b = pd.Categorical(["but", "integer", "where it", "counts"])
>>> pypkgs.catbind(a, b)
[character, hits, your, eyeballs, but, integer, where it, counts]
Categories (8, object): [but, character, counts,
eyeballs, hits, integer, where it, your]
pyexplainer.pyexplainer_pyexplainer.id_generator(size=15, random_state=None)[source]¶

Generate unique ids for div tag which will contain the visualisation stuff from d3.

Parameters

  • param1 (int) – An integer that specifies the length of the returned id, default = 15.

  • param2 (np.random.RandomState, default is None.) – A RandomState instance.

Returns

A random identifier.

Return type

str

Examples

>>> from pypkgs import pypkgs
>>> a = pd.Categorical(["character", "hits", "your", "eyeballs"])
>>> b = pd.Categorical(["but", "integer", "where it", "counts"])
>>> pypkgs.catbind(a, b)
[character, hits, your, eyeballs, but, integer, where it, counts]
Categories (8, object): [but, character, counts,
eyeballs, hits, integer, where it, your]
